Two issues to resolve: 
- Do we want to say "HyperscaleDAO" anywhere, or leave it as "Hyperscale"?  I like the latter as it matches the logo, and the main use of DAO is to refer to applicants and their DAOs in the timeline.  Leaves the door open for DAO / Fund / Bounty

I resubmitted the small copyedits from last night, pending kev's review.

@m1guelpf / @shawn (whoever is updating the timeline) Text should be updated to say Hyperscale rather than HyperscaleDAO (and perhaps shorten the last blurb to '*The community shares the incentive for your DAO to succeed.*' for balance)

The website prominently features "guidance" as the last step of the process -- is that really something a DAO can execute on? Funding transactions are one thing, but actually helping entrepreneurs with real problems is something to take seriously. Bad guidance can be fatal. Guidance can also have legal ramifications. Everything up to that point sounds great, but can a DAO do a good job at guiding? Is there a relationship with the entrepreneur and the DAO that builds trust? It doesn't seem so.

Good question. This was previously chewed on by some folks here. The DAO as a whole advising companies would likely be messy and inefficient. I think appointing expertise-specific representatives from HS for entrepreneurs to consult could be a possible approach. As for the legal ramifications, I defer to legal minds such as @better.law.
I also think setting up a founders channel for networking/crowdfunding ideas could be helpful for low stakes queries/feedback.
Had the same question if applicants have to be a DAO?  Hyperscale might fill a huge need of just helping startups transition to a DAO

Structure mentor relationships to other founders; access to education; who knows maybe even a powerful friend could help get YC style training, etc. to DAO funded companies? Seems like an "integration" with something like YC to say "hey if you need 'normal' startup stuff go here".

Overall -- I think the question I have though is not strategic. It's that right now the website copy is very prominently offering a "standard package" of incubator / venture fund services, but it's only crystal clear how the DAO would fund things, not deliver on these other services. Execute on the one clear thing not mimic multiple things that are hard to understand?
Definitely should not characterize the caliber of guidance at this stage. I'm not giving legal advice here but I'm comfortable with offering guidance myself

Fwiw, my experience has been guidance > money.  Started and ran my own company for 10 years before I formed a mentorship and advisory board - that was the real rocket fuel.  It’s my #1 suggestion for new founders: find a mentor or advisor who has been there.  This isn’t about connections or opening doors - it’s about keeping your head on straight in the insanity of running something you started

How do you feel about the “Receive up to 1 mil by filling a simple application” as our headline? I feel like it is a bit hypey and sounds too good to be true. It would attract lots of get rich quick type of projects which is not very good if we aim to be an investment group that is looking for long term projects. I don’t have a suggestion on a better headline though 😅

On another note it would be good to attract get rich quick projects as our final goal is to have an AI that makes the investment decisions. If we can reliably distinguish the good applications from the sea of bad ones it will be the perfect training data for the AI. It just means we will make more bad investments at the beginning but end up in a better spot in the long term.

I completely agree and had my career shaped by mentors and guidance; I ended up on the board of a nonprofit that creates mentor relationships for CEO's, filmmakers, and other aspirational leaders; and my wife is the founder of an incubator that has structured thousands of relationships to help guide entrepreneurs. I care about it deeply -- and that's why I'm saying it's hard to conceive of how a DAO provides good guidance at this time. There are great ways to handle it. Perhaps there is a point person per company who gets input from the community and funnels down; maybe organic discord scale feedback and swarming is somehow helpful. 

It would be great to see "Guidance -- DAO Style" as a defined thing. Honoring how important Guidance is won't make a DAO good at successful management of long-term relationships. The mechanism for funding is transactional, which it's clear how a DAO can do.
Initial copy (no jobs page) was deployed

Regarding guidance/advise to startups. We could do an MVP, similar to Intro: https://intro.co/

There you have a short profile/bio of the people available for consultation. You book a 15-30min video call and get advice. Front end could be kept simple and booking done via calendly. We could also have a rating system for the advise-seeking so the great advisors float to the top. Of course the difference to Intro is that it should be free of charge for the founders who the fund has backed since it’s a win-win for both fund and entrepreneur. 

This would be a first MVP for founders to bounce off their ideas/questions off somebody experienced in that particular field or to get a starting point in order to continue doing the work themselves.
We should make it more clear on the website what type of Web3 companies we are backing. We need to clarify that we can't invest in pre-token deals

re: mentorship, you essentially want to have a two-sided marketplace where founders express interest in connecting with a mentor, share a simple blurb about their project and why that person is relevant. and then ideally you get that person to commit x amount of time to helping hyperscale companies next week, then they take a look at the blurbs and decide or delegate their decision-making on which projects to spend time with to someone they trust.
you then have someone within the hyperscale team whose role is to go and convince the requested experts or people with the requested expertise to commit some time
this is essentially what we do at HF0

Notion measures out blocks (so a page of text w/ carriage returns but no full returns is one block; each return or  bullet in a list is one block) so our constraint till we settle on a plan is basically # of full returns 🐒   ran a cleanup script so the immediate problem is gone, but we should settle on a long-term plan today

Great start, thanks for doing this. What do you think about using multiselect fields for the bottom questions? 

So instead of "List areas of expertise" you prompt with "In which of the following areas can you support early-stage teams? (check all that apply)" or something like that and then offer options. 

Benefits are 1) easier for them to fill out 2) we get to list the areas of expertise we actually want 3) easier to clean + import into profiles

messages.content:
This is great. I have several areas to add additional questions. I could comment on the google doc but thought it would be clearer here: 

1) A lot of mentor matching comes down to availability. A question set or time grid about their availability and overall time commitment will save a lot of trouble: 
*What time zone are you in? 
*How many hours per month can you commit? 
*Are you available during the work day, or only nights & weekends? 
*Is mentoring / advising a part of your paid professional responsibility set? 

2) Another big driver of mentor relationship success is affinity matching, or psychographic matching. A question set about values and interests will increase successful matching: 
*Do you have an industry or interest niche to which you are narrowly focused? 
*Do you have a preference to work with founders of diverse background? 
*Are you a female or diverse background founder who is more comfortable with culturally similar mentors? 
*Do you have professional restrictions that require advisement to be outside of certain categories, for example if you manage a third party's portfolio or IP and cannot work in that domain? 

3) Last success driver is value-add, so questions like: 
*Can you provide access to resources, discounts, or other special assistance to founders? 
*Do you have a media platform or large audience you are willing to use to support founders? 
*Are you willing to publicly promote the company? 
*Are you interested in receiving commissions and referrals for goals you accomplish for the company?

fwiw I served on the board of a national mentorship nonprofit that structured thousands of executive relationships each year, and my wife started and incubator that has facilitated about four thousand entrepreneur / advisor relationship over the past ten years.

This is great feedback, thank you! I will put it into the doc under further iterations, since what I have put up for now is just something basic that we could get going tomorrow. But fully agree with all you have mentioned. 

On 1) this will be taken care of ideally via the scheduling tech using e.g., calendly. But this is if we go for an intro.co type of service where founders can simply book mentor sessions. Which I was thinking could be MVP 1.0. But then once we get more sophisticated and do proper matching, then these questions would make a lot of sense.

I would be glad to have a detailed design work session sometime on a shared call fwiw. There's a lot of listing services and forward compliance with opportunity listings via API also important. i.e. People find these opportunities in lots of places, not just posts.
